awd_titl_txt: Upstate New York LSAMP: Strengthening the Pipeline Between Two and Four Year Institutions
awd_abstract_narration:
The Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program assists universities and colleges in diversifying the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) workforce through their efforts at significantly increasing the numbers of students from historically underrepresented minority populations (African-Americans, Hispanic Americans, Native Americans, Alaska Natives, Native Hawaiians, Pacific Islanders) to successfully complete high quality degree programs in STEM.   For the  New York State's Upstate Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (ULSAMP), seven partner institutions comprise this alliance: five are 4-year institutions-Syracuse University,  Clarkson University, Cornell University, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, and Rochester Institute of Technology; two are community colleges: Monroe Community College and Onondaga Community College. Syracuse University will develop activities to recruit and retain traditionally underrepresented minority (URM)students into science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) programs of study and careers.

The ULSAMP project goal will collectively graduate 860 STEM URM students per year by the end of 2022 by improving the recruitment, academic success, and persistence of URM students in STEM majors. The alliance plans to expand, refine, and study best practices for preparing community college students for successful transition into four-year STEM programs. Activities will be enhanced by undertaking a research study to investigate the role of research experiences, faculty mentoring, and the community college pipeline on the persistence and graduation of URM students and the implications of these initiatives for increasing representation of URM students in STEM. The alliance project and the associated research project will generate new knowledge related to the recruitment, academic success, and persistence of underrepresented minority STEM students that will be disseminated through social media outlets, alliance websites, e-newsletters, STEM conferences and scholarly journals.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the Upstate Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (ULSAMP) is to recruit, retain, and graduate an increasing number of underrepresented minority (UREP) students in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) fields, and to provide early student research experiences to foster graduate school enrollment. ULSAMP is a partnership between seven institutions in Upstate New York: Clarkson University, Cornell University, Monroe Community College, Onondaga Community College, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Rochester Institute of Technology, and Syracuse University. As a Senior-Level Alliance, ULSAMP has made a deliberate and concerted effort to identify promising practices and share practical knowledge through program offerings, meetings, written reports, and formal and informal discussions. ULSAMP has focused on continuing the progress made over the life of the project and developing new strategies to further increase the enrollment, retention, graduation, and graduate school participation of UREP STEM students, while overcoming challenges faced during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Below are the objectives of the project:

Objective 1: Increase the number of URM students transferring from community colleges to four-year STEM studies at Alliance universities by 75%.

Objective 2: Improve the retention of URMs in STEM majors after their first and second years by 20%.

Objective 3: Increase the total enrollment of URMs in the STEM disciplines by 30%.

Objective 4: Increase the baccalaureate degree attainment of URMs in STEM by 40%.

Objective 5: Increase URM bachelor’s degree recipients pursuing graduate studies in STEM by20%.

 

Below are ULSAMP outcomes over time:

 ●       The total fall enrollment for undergraduate UREP students at ULSAMP institutions increased from 1,943 STEM students in fall 2007 to 4,141 students in fall 2021.

●       The total number of UREP STEM bachelor’s degrees awarded by ULSAMP institutions increased from 249 per year in 2007-2008 to 706 in 2021-2022.

 ●       Since 2007, ULSAMP institutions have awarded 7,559 STEM degrees to UREP students.

 ●       The total number of ULSAMP UREP STEM students entering graduate studies annually increased from 13 in 2012-2013 to 31 in 2019-2020. 

 ●       Each year, over 200 students receive direct funding from ULSAMP.

 ●       The number of ULSAMP mentors has doubled since the program began in 2007. 161 individuals served as mentors to ULSAMP scholars during the 2020-2021 year.

 

ULSAMP students are assisted through initiatives such as seminars, community building, research experiences, recognition events, bridge programs, academic support, mentoring, and professional and career development opportunities. To increase participation in graduate work, all ULSAMP four-year institutions have developed programming to provide the information and skills necessary to successfully apply and be admitted to STEM graduate degree programs. Given the increasing importance of community colleges as an access point to higher education and their central importance in our communities, a major emphasis of ULSAMP is to establish strong partnerships with the alliance two-year institutions, as well as other regional two-year colleges. During this project period, ULSAMP four-year institutions continued to include community college participants in their summer activities, invited students to visit their campuses, and created new initiatives and partnerships to increase the number of community college students transferring to their institutions. The Community College Partnership, launched in fall of 2020, included area community colleges with the purpose of sharing best practices and providing guidance, expertise, and consultation in analyzing and understanding the barriers to academic success, retention, and degree attainment experienced by community college students. ULSAMP believes that to impact the graduation of UREP STEM students in Upstate New York, partners must establish strong linkages between institutions. The ULSAMP institutions leveraged resources to establish additional research opportunities for students and maintained constant communication and collaborative planning throughout the alliance.

To ensure the program is sustainable beyond the funding period, institutionalization efforts have taken the form of new hires to support diversity, belonging, equity and inclusion initiatives, dedicated admissions staff, or additional resources to support the recruitment of UREP students in STEM disciplines, and institutional support for ULSAMP research opportunities. These efforts work together to broaden the scope of program practices and activities at ULSAMP institutions and strengthen future sustainability plans.

Results of the project have been disseminated at various symposia and conferences. The annual ULSAMP Student Leadership Conference, campus-specific research symposia, and conferences  are avenues for ULSAMP students to present their research in a public setting and some ULSAMP students have been listed as authors on publications. As an additional way to disseminate information, program directors facilitated presentations and paper sessions to share the knowledge gained through program development and findings from the research study locally and nationally. Because of the work of ULSAMP, there has been an increase in the number of UREP students entering the STEM pipeline, receiving STEM degrees, and enrolling in graduate programs. The commitment of the alliance in facilitating the success of UREP STEM students is increasing their presence to diversify the field and their matriculation into graduate programs.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 01/02/2024
Modified by: Tamara N Hamilton
